title: Domain 5.3: Given a scenario, troubleshoot common issues with network services.
content:
ğŸ”„ STP (Spanning Tree Protocol)

STP is used to prevent network loops. A failure in STP can lead to broadcast storms and network instability.

Common use: Ensuring STP is enabled and configured correctly to avoid network loops in a redundant switch setup.

ğŸ” Network Loops

Network loops occur when there are multiple active paths between switches, which causes broadcast storms and network congestion.

Common use: Diagnosing network loops and ensuring that STP is configured to block redundant paths.

ğŸ”‘ Root Bridge Selection

The root bridge is the central reference point in a network running STP. Incorrect root bridge selection can lead to suboptimal path selection and network inefficiencies.

Common use: Checking if the correct switch is elected as the root bridge and ensuring that other switches don't incorrectly claim the role.

ğŸ› ï¸ Port Bridge Selection

Port bridge selection determines the best path for data to travel in a switched network. Misconfigurations can cause inefficient routing and delays.

Common use: Reviewing STP settings to ensure the correct port roles (e.g., root, designated, blocking).

ğŸŒ Port Roles

Different port roles determine how ports in a switch participate in data forwarding. Incorrect port roles can cause network outages.

Common use: Ensuring STP port roles are correctly configured to prevent loops and traffic bottlenecks.

ğŸ›‘ Port States

Port states (e.g., Blocking, Listening, Learning, Forwarding) determine the function of switch ports in STP. Incorrect port states can cause traffic issues.

Common use: Checking STP port states to troubleshoot network connectivity problems.

ğŸŒ Incorrect VLAN Assignment

Incorrect VLAN assignment can isolate devices on the same physical network. Ensuring proper VLAN configuration is critical for network segmentation.

Common use: Verifying VLANs and their assignments on switches to ensure devices in the same VLAN can communicate.

ğŸ”’ ACLs (Access Control Lists)

ACLs are used to filter traffic and enforce security policies. Misconfigured ACLs can block legitimate traffic or allow unauthorized access.

Common use: Reviewing ACL configurations to ensure only the correct traffic is allowed or denied.

ğŸ›£ï¸ Route Selection

ğŸ—ºï¸ Routing Table

The routing table determines how packets are forwarded in a network. Incorrect routes can lead to misdirected traffic.

Common use: Checking the routing table on routers to ensure all routes are correct and that there are no conflicting entries.

ğŸ”‘ Default Routes

A default route (often called the "gateway of last resort") is used when no other routes match. A misconfigured default route can cause traffic to fail to reach its destination.

Common use: Verifying the default route in the routing table and ensuring it points to the correct gateway.

ğŸ™ï¸ Address Pool Exhaustion

Address pool exhaustion occurs when there are not enough IP addresses available for devices to use. This is common with DHCP or static IP assignments.

Common use: Checking the DHCP server or static IP assignments to ensure enough IP addresses are available.

ğŸšª Incorrect Default Gateway

An incorrect default gateway can prevent devices from accessing remote networks.

Common use: Verifying the default gateway settings on the device to ensure proper routing.

ğŸ§© Incorrect IP Address

An incorrect IP address can prevent devices from communicating within the local network or the internet.

Common use: Checking and correcting the IP address on the device to ensure it is on the correct subnet.

ğŸ”„ Duplicate IP Address

A duplicate IP address can cause network conflicts and communication failure.

Common use: Checking the network for duplicate IP addresses and resolving the conflict by reassigning a unique address.

ğŸ”¢ Incorrect Subnet Mask

An incorrect subnet mask can prevent a device from correctly identifying other devices on its local network, leading to connectivity issues.

Common use: Verifying the subnet mask on the device and comparing it with the networkâ€™s configuration to ensure proper communication.
